question: Question_06_(a)
statement:
The height of fluid, $h(t)$ in a cylindrical container is controlled by
a pump so that it satisfies the differential equation

\[\frac{dh}{dt} = -kh^{1/3}, \quad h(0)=h_0\] where $k>0$, $h_0>0$ are
constants, and $h_0$ is the initial height of the fluid.

(a) Solve this differential equation to determine the height $h(t)$ at
any later time $t$.
sols:
Using separation of variables we can write

\[\frac{dh}{dt} = -kh^{1/3}\]

as

\[h^{-1/3}\,dh = -k\,dt, \quad \text{which we integrate to get} \quad \int h^{-1/3}\,dh = \int -k\,dt.\]

Both integrals are solved straight forward to yield

\[\frac32 h^{2/3} = -kT+C_1\]

which we solve for \emph{h} to obtain

\[h(t) = \left(C_2 - \frac23 kt\right)^{3/2},\]

where \emph{C\textsubscript{2}} is another constant.

All that's left to do now is to use the initial condition \emph{h(0) =
h\textsubscript{0}} to solve for \emph{C\textsubscript{2}}:

\[h_0 = h(0) = \left(C_2-\frac23k\cdot 0\right)^{3/2}, \quad \text{which yields} \quad C_2 = h_0^{2/3}.\]

Therefore the height \emph{h(t)} at any time \emph{t} is given by

\[h(t) = \left(h_0^{2/3}-\frac23 kt\right)^{3/2}.\]

\emph{To double-check your answer you can take the derivative of h(t)
and check that the given differential equation is indeed satisfied:}

\begin{align*}
\frac{dh}{dt} &= \frac32\left(h_0^{2/3}-\frac23 kt\right)^{1/2} \cdot \left(-\frac23 k\right) \\
&= -k \underbrace{\left(h_0^{2/3}-\frac23 kt\right)^{1/2}}_{= h^{1/3}}
\end{align*}
